author: s1na
content: There's team X from PegaSys, <@!296630428754771968> as well who collected some numbers. I believe a turbo-geth team member is trying to figure out if we can get away mostly with static jumps, which if is the case would be beneficial for code merkleization. I also ran some experiments and am starting work on a draft spec. (and of course others who contributed to the conversation)

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> What do you mean by "get away with static jumps"? Like banning dynamic jumps from the EVM?

author: Deleted User
content: no, it is proving that most (maybe 99.9% or something) deployed contracts cannot jump into an invalid jumpdest (JUMPDEST which in inside the data of a PUSHx instruction). If that proving can be done efficiently before any contract is deployed, then you can a) not do jumpdest analysis for this contract b) merkelise it any way you want

author: Deleted User
content: but the approach we are taking is not just going to be useful for code merklelisation. It may help to potentially identify contracts that have only SSA (static state access), and I suspect most transactions are actually SSA. This can lead to some interesting optimisations related to parallelisation, without having to explicitly mark access lists

author: Deleted User
content: we are doing what it is called "abstract interpretation"

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> Is that the same as symbolic execution? Or something different? (re @eth1x_bridge_bot: <Alexey> we are doing what it is called "abstract interpretation")

author: Deleted User
content: It is different from symbolic execution, because in symbolic execution you are still trying to follow the execution path of some sort. In abstract interpretation, you kind of solving all paths at the same time, you are building a graph of possible jumps

author: gichiba
content: <@!273808422753796097> TeamX from Pegasys did a little shuffling AFAIK <@!636680106630316033> and <@!461762841641484302> are the two to ask -- I think the intuition is that things like static analysis and code chunking based on functionId aren't going to offer witness savings enough to make it worth the effort, but that fixed chunking (of variable or strictly enforced chunk sizes) might be worth it. But data will take a few more weeks to compile
